There's a lot of confusion about what a hard fork is. A hard fork is an upgrade mechanism where everyone adopts an expanded ruleset at a specified time. Many coins use scheduled hard forks to upgrade their networks.

4/ Bitcoin hard forked multiple times over the years, but it wasn't until the August 1st, 2017 hard fork that a currency split happened. One such earlier fork happened in 2013:  https://t.co/5yIj2n8pOa

5/ Soft forks are marketed as better because they are less likely to lead to a currency split. @VitalikButerin makes an excellent argument for why soft forks are coercive: "hard forks are opt-in, whereas soft forks allow users no “opting” at all."   https://t.co/GTYe0XabN7
